articles.headline: Federal Authorities Investigate Firm Linked to Roman Abramovich
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the F.B.I. have been investigating Concord Management, people close to the firm said.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the F.B.I. have been investigating Concord Management, people close to the firm said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are investigating Concord Management, a small investment advisory firm that oversaw billions of dollars in hedge fund investments for the Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, according to people close to the firm.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Enrich

articles.headline: Never Before in American History: The F.B.I. Searches a Former President’s Home
articles.snippet: The search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate is a high-risk gamble by the Justice Department, but Mr. Trump faces risks of his own.
articles.abstract: The search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate is a high-risk gamble by the Justice Department, but Mr. Trump faces risks of his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight between former President Donald J. Trump and the National Archives that burst into the open when F.B.I. agents searched Mr. Trump’s Palm Beach estate has no precedent in American presidential history.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Search of Trump’s Home Pushes Long Conflict Into Public View
articles.snippet: Justice Department officials were worried that the former president had not fully complied with requests to return material taken from the White House that included possible classified information.
articles.abstract: Justice Department officials were worried that the former president had not fully complied with requests to return material taken from the White House that included possible classified information.
articles.lead_paragraph: The search carried out on Monday by the F.B.I. at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home, a law enforcement action with explosive legal and political implications, was the culmination of a lengthy conflict between a president proud of his disdain for rules and officials charged with protecting the nation’s records and secrets.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess, Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: For Older Americans, Health Bill Will Bring Savings and ‘Peace of Mind’
articles.snippet: Starting in 2025, Medicare recipients with prescription drug coverage will not have to pay more than $2,000 annually for medications, a significant savings for some.
articles.abstract: Starting in 2025, Medicare recipients with prescription drug coverage will not have to pay more than $2,000 annually for medications, a significant savings for some.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Pete Spring was diagnosed with dementia in 2016, he and his wife emptied their checking account in part to pay for his prescription drugs, then ran through $60,000 in pension payments before resorting to a charge card to help make sure Mr. Spring had the heart and Alzheimer’s medications he needed to survive — just two of the 11 drugs he took.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Change These Default Settings and Be Happier With Your Tech
articles.snippet: Simple steps can make your smartphone, computer and TV work better for you.
articles.abstract: Simple steps can make your smartphone, computer and TV work better for you.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many default settings buried deep inside our technology make us share superfluous amounts of data with tech companies. In my last column, I went over how to shut those off.

articles.headline: Hunting for Voter Fraud, Conspiracy Theorists Organize ‘Stakeouts’
articles.snippet: A nascent effort to surveil drop boxes for potential fraud is taking shape in at least 10 states, worrying election officials and law enforcement.
articles.abstract: A nascent effort to surveil drop boxes for potential fraud is taking shape in at least 10 states, worrying election officials and law enforcement.
articles.lead_paragraph: One night last month, on the recommendation of a man known online as Captain K, a small group gathered in an Arizona parking lot and waited in folding chairs, hoping to catch the people they believed were trying to destroy American democracy by submitting fake early voting ballots.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Has a Green Mission, but Dirty Partners
articles.snippet: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
articles.abstract: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: RESGUARDO BUENAVISTA, Colombia — At the edge of the Colombian Amazon, in an Indigenous village surrounded by oil rigs, the Siona people faced a dilemma.
articles.byline: By Sarah Hurtes and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Displaced by War, Ukrainians Open a New Front as Entrepreneurs
articles.snippet: Ukrainians forced from their hometowns by Russia’s invasion find some solace, and success, setting up shop in a new city.
articles.abstract: Ukrainians forced from their hometowns by Russia’s invasion find some solace, and success, setting up shop in a new city.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oksana Dudyk scanned a small selection of ornamental plants lining the shelves of her new florist shop, recently opened in this city on Ukraine’s western frontier. Her eye landed on the perfect bloom for a new customer: fuchsia-colored primroses, vivid and lush, ideal for brightening an austere corner.
